title: Metrics
content:
:::note Precision

$$Precision = \frac{TP}{TP + FP}$$

Precision is "what proportion of positive identifications are actually correct?"

Precision is hampered by false positives.
Precision is used in classication tasks, where the problem is simplified into binary classification.

:::

:::note Recall

$$Recall = \frac{TP}{TP + FN}$$

Recall is "what proportion of actual positives are identified correctly?"

Recall is hampered by false negatives, so if you miss certain instances.

Used in classification settings, including binary classification.


:::

:::note Confusion Matrix

A really good visualisation for classification tasks:

![](image-kl85fco6.png)

Precision is the correct box over the sum of the column.

Recall is the correct box over the sum of the row. **Recall = ROW**.

So for class 2 in this example, the precision is 
$$\frac{659}{3+18+659+36+63} = 0.84$$

For class 2, the recall is 
$$\frac{659}{125+34+659+29+153} = 0.659$$

So we can say that the system doesn't do a great job at classifying all class 2 instances at such (meh recall), however when it does predict 2, it's usually correct (high precision).
:::


:::note Intersection over Union (IoU)

Also called the **Jaccard index**.
Formally, it's defined as:

$$
J(A,B) = \frac{|A \cap B|}{|A \cup B|}
$$

Here, sets A and B could be many different things; it depends on the context. They could be the pixels in bounding box A and bounding box B. 
A could be the set of items predicted to be class $x$, while B is the set of items labelled as class $x$. 

Most commonly, people use IoU in object detection, to evaluate prediction bounding boxes, comparing them to ground truth.

![](image-kl9hdgcw.png)

:::

IoU is used in two contexts: either it's in a classification sense (could also be segmentation), or it refers to the overlap of two bounding boxes (usually in the context of object detection).
